content: 2026 will be defined by AI reliably taking work off users' plates, moving beyond surface-level chatbots to comprehensive business process redesign.
Enterprises currently face an "infrastructure year" requiring connector work, Multi-Cloud Platform (MCP) adoption, and distributability to integrate AI effectively.

AI adoption can be categorized into three worlds: software engineers (clear productivity gains), non-engineers building software (democratizing creation), and enterprises (moving slowly, similar to mid-2010s cloud migration).
Claude Code originated as an internal "Claude CLI" within Anthropic's Labs team and rapidly surpassed all other internal coding tools between September and December.
Anthropic's core bet for Claude Code was to allow the model to "cook longer" and operate over fuzzier task definitions.
Surface-level chatbots are not equivalent to comprehensive business process redesign, highlighting a significant enterprise infrastructure gap.

In 2026, enterprise AI will focus on data annotation and lineage work to make data "AI-friendly," MCP adoption for internal services, moving from retrieval to action-taking, and human-in-the-loop decision queuing.

"Distributability" is a term coined by Anthropic for componentizing intelligence to enable enterprise deployment, meeting organizations where they are (e.g., AWS, specific setups, regulatory constraints).
For enterprise embedding, AI components like skills, Agent SDK, storage, and memory need to be available on all three major cloud providers.
In 2026, AI will emerge as a colleague-like entity, exemplified by GitHub Agent HQ integration where users can tag Claude in a PR and return to completed work.
Delegating tasks to AI, similar to delegating to a colleague, requires providing context, setting clear expectations, and offering good examples.
AI is not yet capable of full onboarding, understanding organizational dynamics, or autonomously picking up work.
Near-term AI delegation should focus on clean task chunks with clear success criteria.
